text: To get to work every day, Leonardo Balada has to travel to Paris and to Parisian cafés. But he is not alone: in fact, he has a large circle of companions and collaborators, who, for the most part, are French. The most important of these is the painter Georges Seurat. Seurat is the most famous of the French impressionists. His work has been exhibited in many of the most important international galleries. He has won many international prizes.

To get to work every day, Leonardo Balada has to travel to France. In the late 1800's he was sent to Paris to study under the great Impressionist painter Henri Matisse. In 1900, he moved to Paris to work for Matisse's nephew, the great French painter Georges Braque. In 1904, Balada was invited to join the Paris School of painting. Leonardo Balada's work office is surrounded by a garden, and his work is a kind of meditation on death and the nature of life. In the early 1960s, Balada was one of the most famous and influential painters of France and the first to use color as a way of expressing his feelings. In this photograph, the building is shrouded by a thick layer of clouds, which has made the building appear even more ominous than it actually is. The photograph was taken in the early 1960s, when it was the tallest building in Paris. The building was designed by the architect Louis Kahn.
